newsitem.title: SRI LANKA: RESEARCH ALERT - Sri Lanka seen recovering in 1997.
newsitem.headline: RESEARCH ALERT - Sri Lanka seen recovering in 1997.

text.p: Sri Lanka's economy, which saw low growth in 1996, is likely to recover in 1997 due to improved agriculture and industrial output, a recent strategy report by UBS Global Research and John Keells Stock Brokers said.
A crippling drought between March and August 1996, is expected to restrict gross domestic product (GDP) growth to an estimated 3.7 percent.
Aided by normal power supply and improvements in the manufacturing sector, which accounts for almost 20 percent of overall GDP, growth in 1997 should improve, the report said.
Investors are advised to remain underweight in the hotel sector, which has been hit by a 29.5 percent drop in tourist arrivals, mainly due to the continuing ethnic conflict in the northeast.
An underweight position is also recommended for the motor sector, because the government has frozen public sector expenditure on the purchase of new motor vehicles due to budgetary constraints.
A neutral stance is recommended on manufacturing since companies in this sector are recovering from the ravages of 1996, which could depress earnings in 1997.
